name: Lauren Mowery
bio: Travel + Wine @decanter @forbes @wineenthusiast Freelance writer #Wine, #Food, #Travel, the staples of a life well-lived. Photography my own.

social_posts.post_text:
On July 20, 2022, the latest innovation in the wine industry dropped onto the market. Wine in a box, or rather, a 100% recyclable cylinder, launched as @drinkjuliet_ Wine. What first grabbed my attention, aside from the unique format, was the branding and design. Gorgeous rich colors in butter yellow and cobalt blue, eye-catching gold lettering, abstract swipes, all proclaiming an environmental twist? As a wine expert and reviewer, I try not to buy wine based on pretty labels, but I couldn’t resist the visual allure of Juliet. 
I contacted the company for more information, letting them know I first saw their wines in an Instagram campaign. We ended up chatting about the background of founders and co-CEOs, @allisonluvera and @iamldp and their inspiration for the product. I asked for a sample, skeptical of its good looks and targeted social media marketing. 

The cylinder of Pinot Noir arrived. I took it to a Thanksgiving event and let everyone pour themselves a glass from the spout. The wine sits in a recyclable plastic bladder, like a traditional bag in box wine. The packaging, which holds 1.5 liters, has a carbon footprint that’s 84 percent lower than an equivalent two glass bottles. 

I kept an eye on their facial expressions but paused for an accounting of my own reaction. Delicious! The Pinot Noir tasted of red fruit and spice with elegant satin tannins and a dry, fresh finish. Four of us drained the container before we sat down to dinner, then broke it down for paper and plastic recycling, using the included prepaid, recycled envelope. Voilà. 

I followed up with founders Luvera and De Niro Pipher to learn more about their background, vision, and production experience for Forbes. 

Article link in bio. 

#wine #winetasting #winelovers #JulietWine #DrinkJuliet #boxwine #finewine #PinotNoir #SauvignonBlanc #roséwine #rosewine @Forbes #forbeslife

Join me live on Monday, December 19 at 11 AM ET for a Taste & Chat with @ottellawinery. 

This historic family winery, founded in 1905, sits in Italy’s Lugana DOC wine region near Lake Garda. Today, the fourth generation runs the business, combining a love for wine with modern art. They built a gorgeous contemporary cellar that welcomes guests for tastings.

 If you don’t know the wines of Lugana, here are a few facts to remember: The wines are white, made with the local Turbiana grape; the climate is moderated by cooling breezes off Lake Garda; and the soil is a mix of clay and limestone. These factors combine to create bright, fresh, mineral-driven wines with notes of citrus and almond.

With the guidance of the winery’s agent Maximilian Schweisfurth, I’ll taste four bottles live so we can peel back the grape’s layers of expressions and demonstrate the transparency and versatility of Turbiana.

Of course, the best way to experience the wines of Ottella is to head to Lugana. Max will share tips on visiting and insights to the region’s cultural and culinary identity.
Tune in live on Monday at 11 AM ET / 5 PM Italian time. Because it’s always Five O' Clock somewhere! This time, in Italy. 

……….

Curious about Croatian wine? This event is for you!

Join me for a virtual masterclass of Croatian wine on IG Live @Chasingthevine on February 16 at 1 PM ET with winemakers from the Komarna appellation. The purpose is to explore 3 expressions of Plavac Mali, a red grape indigenous to the southern Croatian region of Dalmatia.

This tasting will introduce you to Komarna, explore Plavac Mali’s breadth of styles, and debate whether this red grape should serve as a flagship wine for Croatia.

The wines we’ll taste:
• Rizman Plavac Mali – elegant at 13.5 ABV
• Terra Madre Plavac Mali Premium – rounded with a bit of Syrah and Cab at 14 ABV, Decanter Silver
• Volarevic Gold Plavac Mali – robust at 15.5 ABV
If you’d like to taste along, you can purchase the wines in advance from @croatianpremiumwine 
https://www.croatianpremiumwine.com/events/

About the Appellation
Komarna is the newest wine region in Croatia. Located in Southern Dalmatia in the Dubrovnik-Neretva County, Komarna hugs the coast of the Adriatic Sea across the water from the Pelješac Peninsula. Composed of seven modern wineries, all certified organic, Komarna is planted primarily with Plavac Mali and Pošip. Tasting rooms perched above vineyards cascading down stony hillsides, boast enviable views of the glittering sea. Komarna is a quiet, wildly beautiful area, worthy of exploring in person, though for now, we’ll settle for tasting in our glasses.

About the Importers
@croatianpremiumwine was founded by Mirena Bagur and her husband Win. Mirena was born and raised in Croatia in the small town of Metkovic in the Dubrovnik-Neretva county in Dalmatia. The two founded the import company to help introduce the wines of Komarna to the US as a part of the greater story of the rich culture of the Neretva Valley and the Dubrovnik-Split region of Dalmatia. They have continued to extend their activities to embrace all of the Croatian wine regions.

*Story link in bio*

Planning your first trip to #Burgundy or Bourgogne, as the French prefer we call it (correctly), can be daunting. Where should you stay, which domaines should you visit, who will have wine to taste or buy, and where can you find value in a market of small vintages and high demand?⁠
⁠
I answer all of these questions and include a sample 5-day program touching on underappreciated appellations, eco-friendly producers, and next-generation vintners in this comprehensive Beginner's Guide to Wine Tasting in Burgundy, France.⁠

Is It Possible To Make A Nonalcoholic ‘Grand Cru’ Quality Wine? This Winemaker Says Yes! Read the article in @Forbes, link in bio. ⁠
⁠
Have you given up or cut back on alcohol, whether spirits, beer, or wine? Would you pay more for Grand Cru quality nonalcoholic wine? ⁠
⁠
For Forbes, I spoke with Johannes Leitz, owner of Weingut Leitz, about his line of NA wines EINS-ZWEI-ZERO and why his ultimate mission is to make a facsimile of fine wine without the booze. ⁠
⁠
Challenges to achieving this include fine-tuning technology and flavor, while convincing consumers to pay more for a higher end NA wine. More money=better fruit=better base wine=better NA wine. ⁠
⁠
@weingutleitz @einszweizero⁠

Are you heading to Greece this summer? Skip the Cyclades and head to the Ionian island of Kefalonia. ⁠
⁠
Kefalonia is the largest Ionian Island, arguably offering the most to see for travelers willing to commit to at least a week’s time. Ancient olive groves, vineyards, and Mediterranean pine forests encircle the mountainous landscape, while charming villages like Fiskardo in the north, and Argostoli in the southwest offer boutiques, cafes, and restaurants in a waterfront setting.⁠
⁠
Because of Kefalonia’s size, lodging matters. Choosing a property on a beach with excellent facilities, health and wellness programs, and thoughtful organic food and drink turn a good trip into a memorable experience you’ll want to repeat. That was the case for me after spending three days at F Zeen Retreat, a resort on the island’s southwestern coast near the village of Lourdata.⁠
⁠
⁠
......................................................................................................................⁠

There are few countries in Africa that can compete with Botswana for safari exclusivity and luxury, as well as abundant wildlife and diverse landscapes. With a population of roughly 2 million, the country is slightly larger than France and slightly smaller than Texas, yet 40% of its land is dedicated to parks and wildlife. Botswana’s government has prescribed a high income, low volume, low impact, ecotourism policy meaning fewer tourists and better protected natural wildernesses. In addition, they have dedicated their army to anti-poaching—one of the reasons the country is a haven for wildlife. In wilderness areas like the depths of the Okavango Delta and it’s surrounds, not only are the safari camps and lodges more ecologically minded and more symbiotic with their environment, but their owner’s efforts and the government’s policies are helping to preserve the country. 

Here’s why Botswana is the sustainable safari destination of 2023 with tips on where to go and where to stay.

Story link in bio. 

#safari #africa #southafrica #wildlife #wildlifephotography #elephant #animalsofinstagram #elephantsafari #africanelephant #animallovers #botswana #zebra #getoutside #sustainablesafari #zambia #kenya #wilderness #regenerativetravel  #exploremore #travels #travelbug #travel #igtravel #hiking #mood #getaway #paradise #instatraveling
Off to #Svalbard #norway #arctic

We have limited time here on Svalbard because our purpose is to learn not vacation. However, the Tourism Cares team set up some fun activities in between conference sessions including an ice cave tour. It’s really challenging to capture the glittering beauty of a frozen underground water channel, but I tried. Converting images to black and white gives a better impression of the contrast. After slipping on crampons, we climbed down into a hole in the mountainside for a 30 minute hike past frozen swirls and diamond crusted walls. The tour ends in a large cavern that looks like the inside of the moon. Our guide explained why they take visitors down: “it is to enjoy the wonders of nature like you would enjoy a piece of art.” @tourismcares @visitnorway #tourismcares #norway #svalbard #norwaynature #norwaytravel #norway🇳🇴 #norvege #getoutside #cave #icelandscape #naturelovers #polarbears

Wine has been integral to Greek culture for over 4,000 years, with its origins dating back to the ancient civilizations of Crete and Mycenae. The Greeks believed that wine was a gift from the gods and played a significant role in their religious ceremonies and daily life. ⁠
⁠
Today, wine remains intimately intertwined with food, culture, and lifestyle. Forgoing a taste of Greek wine or a visit to a winery would be as remiss as visiting Athens and skipping the city’s ancient hilltop sentry, The Acropolis. With the expansion of wine tourism and hospitality facilities, visiting wineries in Greece has never been easier. The only question to answer is whether to pick the Classic Route through the fabled Greek Islands or the Adventurous Route leading deep into northern Greece and The Peloponnese.⁠
⁠
In a recent article for @Forbes, I present the ideal Classic Route from the types of wines produced on Crete and Santorini to where to taste, eat, and sleep. ⁠
⁠
⁠
#winelover #instawine #winetime #whitewine #winestagram #greece #vino #redwine #winetasting #winelovers #wineoclock #winery #winelife #wines #winewednesday #winesofinstagram #winenight #santorini #crete #winesofgreece

In Oslo, I was speaking to a hotel manager about the cost of taking his kids to Disney when he returns to the US this summer. He said the price for his family of four to enter the park before they've bought a soda or souvenir would be $1000. He's not going. How does this story relate to planning a trip to Malawi on a budget? Because the implementation of tourist taxes and rising prices on everything from airfare and hotels to tickets and related fees have the dual effect of curbing crowds while excluding the middle- and lower-income classes from travel and experiences. Is that fair? I'm not sure what the answer is. But like the hotel manager who plans to take his kids to a different park, there are ways to see the world on a budget, in part by visiting less crowded places. Good for the wallet and good for alternative communities.⁠
⁠
Malawi remains overlooked for cultural, safari, and wilderness experiences, yet offers a wide variety of all three for those willing to go their own way.⁠
⁠
Here are my thoughts on how to do Malawi on a budget for Lonely Planet. Add your tips if you have any! And a question for all of you: Should Disney cost $1000 for a family of four, or is that just acceptable capitalism at work?⁠
⁠
⁠
#disneyworld #Disney #orlando⁠
#africa #southafrica #wildlife #wildlifephotography #elephantsafari⁠
#travelbug #bestvacations #travels #wilderness #exploremore #mountain #hiking #igtravel #beachlife #getaway⁠
#socialimpact #panafrican #safari #photosafari⁠
#savetheplanet #sustainability #sustainablestyle #consciousconsumer #sustainableliving #LakeMalawi

The best time to visit Malawi starts in May and runs through October. As writers, tour operators, and travel advisers look to steer readers and guests to less crowded destinations, Malawi should be at the top of the list. Loaded with national parks, friendly villages, hiking and biking trails, and tea farms, all anchored around a spectacular lake, there’s plenty to do for every type of adventurer, even the beach bum.⁠
⁠
I wrote a series of @LonelyPlanet guides to this small, diverse country which you can find linked on my LP bio page. Here’s the first of five to get you started.⁠
⁠

Planning a trip to #Greece this summer? Why not skip the beaten path and head north into wine country. Nemea in the Peloponnese is practically the Napa of Greece with its proximity to Athens. Day trips to @domaineskouras are possible though it’s a lot more fun to spend the night in the charming coastal city of Nafplion. Drink local red wine Agiorgitiko by day and have grilled fish by the sea at night. Or for the truly adventurous at heart, head into northern Greece or Macedonia. You can drive or fly to Thessaloniki then rent a car to visit the Naoussa and Amyndeon, Greece’s coolest climate winemaking regions. Mountains, lakes and villages compose this wilder landscape. The key grape up north is Xinomavro which makes a dry red often referred to as the Barolo of Greece for its similarity to Nebbiolo. Two wineries with great hospitality and good wines are @kiryianni and @alpha_estate 

Link in bio to story detailing how to plan this adventurous trip through Greek wine country.

I’m in Sicily for en primeur, the debut of the latest wine vintage. Before the 2-day showcase including master classes and tastings, the attending journalists are spread around the island to visit wineries in different regions. Today, before even a drop of wine was tasted (ok, not counting lunch), my group (which includes David Ransom), visited a memorial to a village destroyed in 1968 by an earthquake. 

The destruction of Gibellina was tragic for several reasons, some too complex to drop into a social media post, but let’s say the regional government didn’t handle the aftermath well. People were left in the cold in tents to suffer. A new town was built but to memorialize the old one, artist Alberto Burri designed a concrete, sand, and aluminum white “coffin” that follows the perimeter of the old village called Cretto di Burri. It took ten years to complete. 

It’s both a site of remembrance for locals and a tourist attraction that’s so far off the beaten path, it’s worth going for that reason alone. In other words, to experience a rugged, rural, crowd- and glitz-free part of Sicily so rarely covered by mainstream media that truly pays homage to the local community. 

Here are some photos from the site.

@lindafoltran @just_sicily @ab_comunicazione

Pleasures of Sicily. 

Want to know why, no matter how “good” you are, staying fit as a wine and food journalist is hard? Because every winery, especially in Italy, feeds you. And you have to try it, from the fresh-pressed olive oil, bread from locally-milled grains, roasted salted almonds, almond paste sweets maybe by nuns down the country block, to tiny sandwiches with regional cheese, artichoke spread, and cured meats the winemaker calls “nothing special” but would probably cost you $30 for a 12” in NYC and earn the sandwich maker a James Beard award with lines around the block, wrapped twice. The question I always ask is why Americans demand so little quality and taste from their food when we pay so much for it. *sigh*
Enjoyed at winery @assuli.winery in Western Sicily and they accept consumer appointments!

Yep, I’ll taste olive oil all day long. 

Today’s second winery visit was Tenuta Gorghi Tondi in Trapani. The family owners specialize in Grillo, Zibibbo, Nero d’Avola, Perricone, and Syrah. The certified organic property sits along the perimeter of a WWF reserve which protects rare species of birds and a tiny turtle that nests on the shores of a series of lakes in the limestone (think cenotes, thanks David Ransom). They produce high quality wines, including a few unusual and heritage styles like an exquisite late harvest Grillo with botrytis (only 32 euros!) and a pre-British or Alto Grado Grillo that’s late harvested for 16% alcohol, made in an oxidative style but not fortified (hence “pre” British fortification of Marsala wines.) 

In addition to the fascinating stories about the wines, we learned about the heavy Tunisian influence found on Sicily’s west coast, which encompasses much of the essence and heart of Sicilian culture-it’s a blend of people and their traditions. Cous cous with fish, a typical west coast dish, is further delineated into micro-regions by the size of the cous cous. Trapani cous cous has the smallest pasta, while Marsala and Mazara have a larger size. So you know where the cook is from based on the size of your couscous! 

Finally, we tasted the olive oils, pictured. The bread for dipping is called black bread of castel vetrano. It’s made from tumminia flour, an ancient grain specific to the region used historically in the production of this darker whole grain bread. 

Phew. A lot of info packed into one tasting! You don’t have to go far in Sicily to discover myriad traditions only a few miles away.

Serra Ferdinandea: a wine story about bees, bugs, berciasacchi, and lost land. 

Long ago, an island appeared in the Strait of Sicily. The French and Italians disputed its ownership until the volcanic islet disappeared forever back into the sea. 

The moral of the story? The folly of seeking control over impermanence.

Nothing lasts forever. But due to human activity, the stability of the planet’s ecosystems is rapidly unraveling. The constant of financial markets, our homes, our food supply — not guaranteed and yet it relates directly to human behavior. 

Agriculture las largely been at odds with nature. Clearing land for wine grapes isn’t natural. Can we do better? That’s the question biodynamic and regenerative farming hopes to answer. That’s the most important question for the wine industry in 2023.

Deep in the hills of western Sicily, a vineyard has been born. Surrounded by forest and wildflowers, the founders decided to protect the ecosystem, including the soil structure with its colonies of microbes.
The theory: wine can exist as part of a multi-functional system. Equilibrium between people, nature, and crops is possible. The families behind Serra Ferdinandea added colonies of native bees, planted a special chickpea to return nutrients to the soil, and revived an ancient grain called Berciasacchi to hand harvest for bread and pasta because these were the historical varieties the ecosystem had long adapted to. 

Two days ago, we drove up the rugged roads past dense fields of wildflowers buzzing with insects, to taste the products of the land in situ. 

What struck me was the frisson of life. The landscape breathed and exhaled. Life, living, alive. 

I thought of the chemicals we spray for the perfect lawn, to kill insects we don’t like, for a sweeping view of dead space. The hours spent growing and mowing. The HOAs demanding turf when native plants thriving with the critters that rely on them taps into the human experience in a fundamental and life-affirming manner our current ways of doing business erode. And erosion at its worst looks like a collapse of the very systems that support human life. What a paradox we can’t see this. @serraferdinandea

A whimsical jasmine-covered watchtower or ivory tower, for a play on words, with sea and Mt Etna views inside Radicepura gardens. Today’s final wine  tasting is inside the glass walls while outside nature blooms from the bounty of rain. Ahhh, Sicily, you goddess. @radicepura

On assignment at another gorgeous hotel, this time in Charleston. Stayed one night at The Dewberry. The Dewberry, a member of Historic Hotels of America since 2016, dates back to 1964 when it served as an office for federal workers. Logically, during renovations of the seven-story “skyscraper” (no building height may surpass the tallest church steeple in the Holy City), hoteliers opted for slick a mid-century modern vibe. 

My suite overlooks two churches, features a soaking tub in the bath, a seating area outfitted in leather and teak, and a four-poster king bed. 

Last night, I had the chance to hit the roof for cocktails and oysters at Citrus Club, so naturally I needed a chic dress. The ladies of Charleston love floral gowns. I met them in the middle with this ankle-length 🦩-patterned silk charmeuse number from my favorite California designer Heidi Merrick. She likes 80s throwback shoulder pads and honestly, they work! Thoughts— on the dress or hotel?? Has anyone stayed here?

Oh, Santorini

Even jaded travelers fall for Santorini, an ancient island rising from the azure embrace of the Aegean Sea, the southernmost island of the region PGI Cyclades. To a backdrop of whitewashed homes perched upon volcanic cliffs, fiery sunsets paint the heavens with strokes of molten gold, while wanderers and romantics watch nature’s spectacle with a glass of Assyrtiko wine. The island practically writes its own poetic prose.

Wine is an integral part of the lives of the Cycladic people. Traditional cultivation methods, bright sunshine, proximity to the sea, and a Mediterranean climate contribute to the uniqueness of the wines of PGI Cyclades. Almost all of the Cyclades has wine production, however, the vineyards of Santorini are some of the oldest in the world. 

Adding to Santorini’s charm is its rich winemaking legacy, intricately linked to the island’s volcanic soils. Winemaking dates to ancient times, when the Greeks were the first to cultivate grapes on the island. Today, Santorini boasts a PDO (Protected Designation of Origin) that focuses on Assyrtiko, a distinct and celebrated grape uniquely tied to the island.
Domaine Sigalas, one of the leading wineries in Santorini, epitomizes the trend of high-end winemaking that’s grown for two decades. Sigalas prides itself on farming local grapes and using traditional winemaking methods that showcase the exceptional terroir of the island in its range of lauded wines.

In recent years, there has been renewed interest in Santorini’s volcanic soil and its profound impact on the island’s wines. This attention and a marked increase in quality have helped elevate Santorini’s vinous reputation. Global demand has helped raise prices, a welcome boon to the island’s multi-generational farmers. As winemakers continue experimenting and innovating with Assyrtiko, the possibilities for this region will grow.

Traveling to Santorini? See link in bio for tips

Crete…

I visited Crete in September 2021 for two weeks and fell in love. Crete boasts a long winemaking legacy that dates back thousands of years to the Minoans. They were among the first civilizations in Europe to cultivate grape varieties, contributing to the spread of winemaking culture in Greece. Fun fact: during a tour of Knossos, we learned that Minoans were the first to create the disposable party cup!

Given the ease of agriculture, Crete feeds much of Greece with its abundant produce. Even the origins of the Mediterranean diet can be traced to Crete. The island’s diverse terrain and favorable climate favor grape cultivation, an important economic and cultural industry.

Today, local wineries are increasingly focusing on indigenous grapes, which are growing in popularity with consumers worldwide. @douloufakiswinery leads this trend, embracing a fine winemaking approach emphasizing local grapes and sustainable practices. The winery produces labels under both PGI Crete and PDO Dafnes.

When Nikos Douloufakis inherited his family’s vineyards, he set out to revitalize heritage varieties on the cusp of extinction. For example, he produces Vidiano, known for crisp, bright whites, and Liatiko, capable of fragrant, vivid reds. His efforts have helped raise global awareness of Crete’s rich winemaking history while catching the eye of sommeliers and tastemakers who now seek out the wines of Crete for their restaurant lists and retail shelves.

For more information on traveling in Crete, see link in bio!

The Peloponnese

One of the key mythological stories from Greece’s Peloponnese is the tale of the Labors of Hercules. This legendary hero, driven mad by the goddess Hera, was charged with completing twelve impossible tasks. His triumph over ferocious beasts and daunting challenges symbolizes strength, courage, and the indomitable human spirit, similar to this ancient region’s winemaking industry.

Today, mythological heroes aside, the PGI Peloponnese region boasts the largest winemaking industry in Greece, offering a range of white and red grapes like Moscofilero, a fragrant white wine known for its floral aromatics, as well as Assyrtiko, Mavrodaphne, and Roditis.  

PDO Nemea, located to the northeast, is the most prolific red wine appellation dedicated to cultivating Agiorgitiko. The Agiorgitiko variety is best known for medium-bodied, dry reds with fruity undertones and hints of baking spices. However, this versatile grape also yields dry roses and luscious dessert wines.

Located in the village of Argos, at the heart of Nemea, Domain Skouras (@domaineskouras) skillfully showcases the region’s terroir. The winery’s vineyards are situated in the mountains, with some reaching elevations of over 3,500 feet. Founder George Skouras set out to showcase the area’s authentic terroir, including the delineation of microclimates, by crafting wines of purity and expressiveness.

Although Agiorgitiko remains the beating heart of Domain Skouras, the winery produces several different labels. Megas Oenos, a blend of 80% Agiorgitiko, and 20% Cabernet Sauvignon, is one of the most lauded wines in Greece for its quality and aging potential. Domaine Skouras also makes white wines from Moscofilero. Whether you love rosé, red, or white, there’s something for everyone.

If you’re considering traveling to Peloponnese, see the link in the bio for advice on building a memorable trip.

Let’s talk Northern Greece

Macedonia, an area long known for its prized cherries, has earned a reputation for fine wine. Though its newfound acclaim for wine happened in the last few decades, the area has a rich history of winemaking dating back centuries. The greater PGI Macedonia area includes several regions like PDO Naoussa, PGI Imathia, PGI Florina, and PDO Amyndeon. The climate and landscape of PGI Macedonia and specifically Naoussa, provide excellent growing conditions for the Xinomavro grape, the region’s flagship red, which produces full-bodied, high-acid, tannic wines with earthy undertones.  

@kiryianni is a key player, producing some of the finest wines in the area. The winery was founded in 1997 by Yiannis Boutaris, a leading figure in the Greek wine industry. Kir-Yianni focuses on innovation and experimentation by using both traditional winemaking methods alongside modern techniques to create high-quality wines.

The Xinomavro grape is at the heart of Kir-Yianni’s winemaking, and the winery produces a range of styles, from young and fruity to oak-aged and complex. Their goal as winemakers is to highlight the local terroir that makes northern Greece unique and a world-class wine region. When it comes to their reds, wines show firm tannins and high acidity with dark berry and savory notes and aging potential that rivals some of the world’s great reds.

In addition to Xinomavro, Kir-Yianni produces other wines such as Assyrtiko and Chardonnay. Their Assyrtiko wines are a standout, with bright acidity and minerality, making them a popular choice among wine enthusiasts.  Due to the cooler climate, most of their white wine production is centered in the PGI Florina vineyards.

Northern Greece’s reputation as a premium winemaking region is on the rise, and Kir-Yianni winery is at the forefront of this movement.

If you’re considering traveling to Macedonia, see link in bio for advice on building a memorable trip.

Amyndeon

Alexander the Great, the famous conqueror born in Macedonia, and his tutor Aristotle, both profoundly influenced the region’s cultural and intellectual landscapes. Another notable influence on the region’s physical landscape is the cultivation of wine grapes.

Located in the remote mountains of Northwestern Greece, the Amyndeon region has been producing wines for centuries. Despite its relative obscurity in the wine world, its unique climate and terrain have produced some of Greece’s most exceptional wines, with the Xinomavro grape as the region’s flagship variety.

Xinomavro produces full-bodied, high-acid red wines with an unmistakable earthy character and firm tannic structure. It is often compared to Italy’s Nebbiolo grape.
Amyndeon’s cool climate, mountainous terrain, and significant diurnal temperature range make it an ideal place for Xinomavro. 

High-elevation vineyards give grapes freshness and acidity, while dry summers ensure ripeness and concentration. The region’s stony soil provides ideal drainage, producing good-quality grapes.

Though winemaking in Amyndeon dates to ancient times, the region’s modern-day winemaking history is young. It wasn’t until the late 1990s that the region gained international recognition with Alpha Estate Winery as the leading force. @alpha_estate 

Alpha Estate Winery, established in 1997, quickly gained acclaim for its wines, and has become the region’s most significant producer and thought leader. Alpha Estate’s approach to winemaking, which emphasizes innovation, experimentation, and the expression of terroir, has helped raise the region’s profile.

Today, Amyndeon’s reputation as a premium winemaking region continues to grow. Recognition for Xinomavro’s quality, unique character, and great value, makes it a popular choice among enthusiasts.
If you’re considering traveling to Macedonia, see link in bio for advice on building a memorable trip.

Stylish and contemporary spots in Yerevan abound, many embracing the on-trend arch motif already embedded in the city’s architecture in part due to Soviet architects like Alexander Tamanyan and his student Mark Grigoryan employing neo-classic design (with a little art deco thrown in). Full circle. Thanks to my amazing guide @arpiyeganyan for the insightful two day city tour. Book her services at @wild_adventures_armenia 
#Yerevan, #Armenia #yerevancity #armenian #armeniancuisine

Beautiful #Yerevan, #Armenia  Known as “The Cascade,” the complex was originally conceived by the architect Alexander Tamanyan (1878–1936). Tamanyan desired to connect the northern and central parts of the city—the historic residential and cultural centers of the city—with a vast green area of waterfalls and gardens, cascading down one of the city’s highest promontories. Thank you to my amazing guide @arpiyeganyan for showing me the city. #armenian #armenia🇦🇲 #armenians #yerevancity

Eating all the things with @arpiyeganyan on our tour of the Nork District. We stopped at Norki Keghar Winery @norqikegharwines established in 1877, for a feast of #food and #wine. Saw the old cellar filled with karas (amphorae), tasted 7 wines, ate peaches and figs off the trees in the garden, and settled in for a multi-course feast. Thanks to my awesome guide @arpiyeganyan , who you can book through @wild_adventures_armenia, for showing me this historic off-the-beaten path wine district.

Can’t stop eating in #yerevan. What an amazing food city. It’s also a paradise for vegetarians. Today’s gastro tour with @2492.travel has taken me to six spots for local fare including this dish called manti, crispy meat dumplings served in broth, topped in matsun (yogurt) sprinkled with sumac. Heaven is a tiny perfect dumpling in the mouth. #armenia #foodtour #yerevanlife #armenianfood

A fashion shoot at the temple of Garni! Having a little fun while enjoying this ancient temple in #Armenia 40 minutes outside of #Yerevan. 

……

I’m always looking for fashionable travel clothes and am happy I put this comfy ensemble together for an outing to Armenia’s classic sites. Achok Safari Shirt by @hmerrick; slip skirt in bronze by @jennikayne; vegan sustainable sunbeam shoes by @koio 

…..

The Temple of Garni is the only standing Greco-Roman colonnaded building in Armenia and the former Soviet Union. Built in the Ionic order, it is located in the village of Garni, in central Armenia, around 30 km east of Yerevan. It is the best-known structure and symbol of pre-Christian Armenia.

#travel #travellife #travelclothes #armeniatravel #armenialife #yerevanlife #getoutdoors #wine #winelife #lifestyle #getthelook #getthelookforless #ancienthistory

Armenia is full of wonders, from wine, food, culture to ancient temples and monasteries. But the best thing I’ve done on this trip is enjoy a macro view of the country by taking to the skies. I had an amazing hot air balloon ride with the professional team behind @skyball_armenia. Working out of #Yerevan, they pick guests up in the city at 6 am for the 40 minute ride to Garni for a sunset and bubbles balloon ride. We saw the gorge and agricultural fields, but the best part was a glimpse of snow-dusted Mount Ararat in the distance. I even made some new friends from #uruguay and #argentina of #Armenian descent who invited me to visit their Armenian restaurant outside of Punta del Este next time I’m in the neighborhood. Cheers to @skyball_armenia, new friends and beautiful #armenia

If you’re looking for a design-forward property in Tbilisi, check out Bazzar Boutique Hotel. @bazzarhotel. 

What you need to know

Location
Sits in a buzzing historic neighborhood of Tbilisi, Georgia on Pkhovi Street near Orbeliani Square. The hotel’s modern facade juxtaposes naturally against nearby heritage buildings. The location is mere footsteps from the new gourmet marketplace Bazar Orbeliani and Atoneli Street and its many restaurants and cafes.

Design
Offers a boho Parisian vibe with vintage-evocative chairs and tables, accented by bold colors like sunflower yellow tile work, saffron velvet textiles, and oversized royal purple plant containers filled with green palm fronds. 

What
Small property with 20 guest rooms and suites with a common area used for breakfast, lunch and dinner that invites both locals and guests to soak up the area's rich and eclectic history.

Why stay here
Great staff, good food, intimate vibe and affordable prices for boutique digs. 

I’ll definitely be back.

At the @gurjaaniwinefest “wine quality ran the gamut from homemade, testing commercial waters to wines worthy of export. However, writing tasting notes and assessing quality was not the purpose of the party. Rather, snacking on grilled meat and local cheese, sipping new grapes, chatting with young and old, listening to their stories and ambitions, and giving oneself over to the movement and energy of the event reaped the most fun and rewarding experience” writes Lauren Mowery for @forbes 

As a guest of the Georgian National Tourism Administration, I had the privilege to attend the Gurjaani Wine Festival. Held on October 14, 2023, the Gurjaani Wine Festival returned for its fifth iteration since 2017. This convivial gathering brought together both large wineries and family-run cellar doors with the purpose of celebrating the heritage and diversity of Georgian wine and its nearly 500 indigenous varieties.

Link in bio to read why attending a regional wine festival offers as deep an insight into local culture as a series of winery visits. In essence, do both.

Charlestoninans & friends: join Slow Food Charleston for a night of Slow Wines from Italy on November 7. We’ll gather between 5-7 PM for Italian snacks and sips at Obviouslee Marketing at 654 King Street with special guest Marilena Barbera of Cantine Barbera in Sicily. RSVP at charlestonsc@slowfoodfoodusa.org (or DM me.)
Ahhh, #charleston, you do outdoor space so well. Loving the new bar and courtyard @theryderhotel on the peninsula.

Finally made it to the #greatsmokymountains. A 4.5-hour drive from #Charleston brings you to the park entrance and the gorgeous @theswagnc retreat, located at 5100 feet elevation. This @relaischateaux property embodies high-brow country rustic living. Notoriously difficult to book a stay due to perennial popularity, I’m lucky to squeeze in 2 nights before the holidays and the seasonal winter closure in December. Hikes, yoga, cocktail classes, spa time, and fireplaces fill the days at this enclave. @arielhturner was right -  a spectacular place! Have you been to @theswagnc? If so, drop your thoughts in the comments! @visitnc

All good things come to an end, including a quick 2-night stay @theswagnc. Sad to depart after creating good memories and meeting new friends in a short time. But it’s better to go wanting more, so I’ll indeed be back next year. Turns out November is a fabulous time to visit, even tho the leaves are down, the vistas are stunning, the fireplaces cozy, and the music and food nourishing. The resort closes in December and reopens in March. See ya on the other side of 2023, @theswagnc!

My new favorite destination in Europe during winter is #Norway. I long eschewed touching the European continent outside of the summer and fall months, but as over tourism heats up in beautiful areas like Norway's fjords, we have to start thinking about how we travel and when, which includes opening our minds to "off-season" periods. Of course, the Norwegians would disagree that winter is a less than desirable time to visit; as they say, there's no bad weather, just bad clothes. 

Nevertheless, my mind changed and expanded, as travel tends to do for us, and now I'm anxious to go back and ice camp in Svalbard. Who's coming with me? 

Link to Forbes article in bio.

I’m building a guide to London’s best — and most sustainable — hotels. First up, the playful @staytreehouse hotel in Mayfair. The property sits on the top floor of a nondescript building, but imbues festive flair and whimsy into its spaces with lots of charming details from the restaurants, bars to guest rooms. Great city views are the icing on this sustainable cake!  #london #londontravel #londonlife #londonhotels #londoncity #londonhotspots #visitlondon #londonlove #greatbritain #sustainable #sustainableliving #sustainabletravel #travel #traveltips

I spent a week exploring London’s increasingly sustainable hotels, from a grand dame, a treehouse, to the modern-meets-timeless classic that is @editionlondon. Enjoyed a few nights learning about the hotel’s sustainability efforts while drinking and dining in @thepunchroom and @bernerstavern. A great location, it’s walking distance to the sights and shops of the city. #london #sustainability #hotels #luxurytravel #sustainable #sustainableliving #sustainablehotel #theedition #londonlife #london🇬🇧 #londonfood #londonrestaurants

This is not a “make flying great again” post, it’s a “make flying great” post. 

What a week. @united airline cancellations for plane maintenance on Max 9s and loose bolts plus weather in Chicago. Double cancellations! 

I took the proactive move, however, to change a flight pattern at the urging of a United text with the promise of change fee waivers, then paid a fee anyway in a panic to get one of few seats left, figuring I’ll deal with customer service afterwards.  Despite being a loyal platinum flier who goes out of her way for their sometimes inconvenient flight plans. In the meantime, I’ve been enjoying the nostalgic pics of Pan Am flights in a FB group. I recognize the wildly expensive fares of the jet-set era (biz class in particular in today’s money ran tens of thousands) and that only a small cohort of people had the opportunity to fly back then, but damn, how classy and fun does flying look then. 

Today, the airlines have created a multi-tier class system that nickel-and-dimes (first they came for our bags, then they came for our seat selections, then they devalued our mileage programs into spending programs), forcing distinctions between people who have a little extra cash and those who don’t, despite forcing apart families that can’t buy seats together or forcing extra fees on body types like those who are taller or wider to pay for extra room, like an exit row that doesn’t even recline. 

Bring Pan Am back. Pride in work, pride in flying, pride in serving. Did you know the first pilots flew WW2 fighter jets? 

Today, it’s a race to the bottom. Who will win? And once they do, then what? Is there an innovation on the horizon that will improve conditions? Please drop your thoughts in the comments.
Travel + Wine @decanter @forbes @wineenthusiast Freelance writer #Wine, #Food, #Travel, the staples of a life well-lived. Photography my own.
